Getter functions

Source: vignettes/2_Getters.Rmd
2_Getters.Rmd
require(Rcongas)
#> Loading required package: Rcongas
#> ✓ Loading Rcongas, 'Copy-Number genotyping from single cells'. Support : <https://militeee.github.io/Rcongas/>

We show how you can access information from a CONGAS computation, using this package. Some functions might be only available for certain model objects, in that case errors are thrown.

In this vignette we use the default model (MixtureGaussian).

Getters available in rcongas

We work with an example object released with the tool.

data('congas_example', package = 'Rcongas')

print(congas_example)
#> ── [ Rcongas ] My CONGAS model n = 503 cells with i = 70 segments, grouped in k
#> ● Cluster c1, n = 379 [75.35% of total cells].
#> ● Cluster c2, n = 124 [24.65% of total cells].
#> 
#> ── CNA highlights
#> ✓  4 CNA(s):  chr14:93300001:105450000, chr15:67050001:102600000, chr16:1:3750000, and chr18:32400001:55950000
#> ℹ Model scored with AIC = 577427.35
#> ● Differential Expression analysis for 1 vs 2 with the DESeq2 method: 212 DE
#> genes at level alpha 0.01, with |lfc| > 0.25.

Reference information

  • get_reference_genome, get_gene_annotations to obtain information about the used reference.

The gene locations for the reference genomes supported by congas can be obtained by using get_gene_annotations.

Note that the reference genome id is stored in the rcongas object created at the time the analysis is performed. So the genome coordinates of the genes are consistent with the adopted reference.

# The adopted reference genome
get_reference_genome(congas_example)

# Gene coordinates as of the reference
get_gene_annotations(congas_example)

Clustering results

  • get_k, get_clusters_size, get_clusters_ploidy to obtain information about the output clusters;
  • get_clusters to obtain clustering assignments.

You can obtain the value fit for \(k\geq 1\), the number of clusters/ clones in the CONGAS model, using get_k. For every cluster, you can also obtain the total number of cells assigned to that, as well as its normalised value (i.e., the mixing proporitions).

# Best number of clusters/ clones in the CONGAS model fit
get_k(congas_example)
#> [1] 2

# Cluster size
get_clusters_size(congas_example)
#>  c1  c2 
#> 379 124

# Cluster size (normalised)
get_clusters_size(congas_example, normalise = TRUE)
#>        c1        c2 
#> 0.7534791 0.2465209

Then you can also obtain the CNA profile estimated for each one of the \(k\) clones, using get_clusters_ploidy. This reports, for every segment the lognormal CNA value estimated by CONGAS, as well as the segment mean, and the CN value (which is the offset to the mean of the segment). Values from this getter can be automatically filtered for certain chromsome ids, and clusters.

# Get all data (all clones, all chromsomes)
get_clusters_ploidy(congas_example)
#> # A tibble: 140 x 8
#>    chr        from        to cluster       CN segment_mean lognorm_CN highlight
#>    <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl> <lgl>    
#>  1 chr1          1  12600000 1        0.0436          1.20       1.25 FALSE    
#>  2 chr1   12600001  60150000 1        0.0165          1.58       1.60 FALSE    
#>  3 chr1   61200001  77100000 1       -0.0427          1.32       1.28 FALSE    
#>  4 chr1   78750001 156000000 1        0.0184          1.59       1.61 FALSE    
#>  5 chr1  156000001 249300000 1        0.00960         1.51       1.52 FALSE    
#>  6 chr2          1  26250000 1        0.0797          1.62       1.70 FALSE    
#>  7 chr2   26250001  38100000 1        0.0139          1.31       1.33 FALSE    
#>  8 chr2   64050001  87150000 1       -0.00652         1.49       1.48 FALSE    
#>  9 chr2   88350001 159900000 1       -0.0418          1.52       1.48 FALSE    
#> 10 chr2  159900001 176850000 1        0.0247          1.24       1.27 FALSE    
#> # … with 130 more rows

# Zoom in one specific chromosome
get_clusters_ploidy(congas_example, chromosomes = 'chr2')
#> # A tibble: 14 x 8
#>    chr        from        to cluster       CN segment_mean lognorm_CN highlight
#>    <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl> <lgl>    
#>  1 chr2          1  26250000 1        0.0797          1.62       1.70 FALSE    
#>  2 chr2   26250001  38100000 1        0.0139          1.31       1.33 FALSE    
#>  3 chr2   64050001  87150000 1       -0.00652         1.49       1.48 FALSE    
#>  4 chr2   88350001 159900000 1       -0.0418          1.52       1.48 FALSE    
#>  5 chr2  159900001 176850000 1        0.0247          1.24       1.27 FALSE    
#>  6 chr2  176850001 195450000 1       -0.0168          1.47       1.46 FALSE    
#>  7 chr2  201750001 243300000 1        0.00915         1.42       1.43 FALSE    
#>  8 chr2          1  26250000 2       -0.0797          1.62       1.54 FALSE    
#>  9 chr2   26250001  38100000 2       -0.0139          1.31       1.30 FALSE    
#> 10 chr2   64050001  87150000 2        0.00652         1.49       1.50 FALSE    
#> 11 chr2   88350001 159900000 2        0.0418          1.52       1.56 FALSE    
#> 12 chr2  159900001 176850000 2       -0.0247          1.24       1.22 FALSE    
#> 13 chr2  176850001 195450000 2        0.0168          1.47       1.49 FALSE    
#> 14 chr2  201750001 243300000 2       -0.00915         1.42       1.41 FALSE

# Zoom in one specific cluster, here "1"
get_clusters_ploidy(congas_example, clusters = '1')
#> # A tibble: 70 x 8
#>    chr        from        to cluster       CN segment_mean lognorm_CN highlight
#>    <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl> <lgl>    
#>  1 chr1          1  12600000 1        0.0436          1.20       1.25 FALSE    
#>  2 chr1   12600001  60150000 1        0.0165          1.58       1.60 FALSE    
#>  3 chr1   61200001  77100000 1       -0.0427          1.32       1.28 FALSE    
#>  4 chr1   78750001 156000000 1        0.0184          1.59       1.61 FALSE    
#>  5 chr1  156000001 249300000 1        0.00960         1.51       1.52 FALSE    
#>  6 chr2          1  26250000 1        0.0797          1.62       1.70 FALSE    
#>  7 chr2   26250001  38100000 1        0.0139          1.31       1.33 FALSE    
#>  8 chr2   64050001  87150000 1       -0.00652         1.49       1.48 FALSE    
#>  9 chr2   88350001 159900000 1       -0.0418          1.52       1.48 FALSE    
#> 10 chr2  159900001 176850000 1        0.0247          1.24       1.27 FALSE    
#> # … with 60 more rows

# Zoom in one specific chromosome and cluster
get_clusters_ploidy(congas_example, chromosomes = 'chr2', clusters = "1")
#> # A tibble: 7 x 8
#>   chr        from        to cluster       CN segment_mean lognorm_CN highlight
#>   <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl> <lgl>    
#> 1 chr2          1  26250000 1        0.0797          1.62       1.70 FALSE    
#> 2 chr2   26250001  38100000 1        0.0139          1.31       1.33 FALSE    
#> 3 chr2   64050001  87150000 1       -0.00652         1.49       1.48 FALSE    
#> 4 chr2   88350001 159900000 1       -0.0418          1.52       1.48 FALSE    
#> 5 chr2  159900001 176850000 1        0.0247          1.24       1.27 FALSE    
#> 6 chr2  176850001 195450000 1       -0.0168          1.47       1.46 FALSE    
#> 7 chr2  201750001 243300000 1        0.00915         1.42       1.43 FALSE

Then you can also obtain the clustering assignments for each one of the input cells, using function get_clusters. This getter can also subset cells in order to contain only those that belong to a specific set of clusters.

# Get all cells at once
get_clusters(congas_example)
#> # A tibble: 503 x 5
#>    cell               cluster    c1    c2 p_assignment
#>    <chr>              <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>
#>  1 AAACCTGTCGACAGCC-1 c2          1     0            1
#>  2 AAAGATGGTAATAGCA-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  3 AACACGTAGCTATGCT-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  4 AACTCCCAGACAGGCT-1 c2          1     0            1
#>  5 AACTCCCGTACACCGC-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  6 AACTGGTCAAAGAATC-1 c2          1     0            1
#>  7 AACTGGTCAAAGTGCG-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  8 AACTTTCGTGGCTCCA-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  9 AACTTTCTCGGTTAAC-1 c2          1     0            1
#> 10 AAGACCTAGCCAGTAG-1 c2          1     0            1
#> # … with 493 more rows

# Subset to cluster "c1"
get_clusters(congas_example, clusters = 'c1')
#> # A tibble: 379 x 5
#>    cell               cluster    c1    c2 p_assignment
#>    <chr>              <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>
#>  1 AAAGATGGTAATAGCA-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  2 AACACGTAGCTATGCT-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  3 AACTCCCGTACACCGC-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  4 AACTGGTCAAAGTGCG-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  5 AACTTTCGTGGCTCCA-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  6 AAGCCGCGTTGTACAC-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  7 AATCCAGCATTTCAGG-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  8 AATCCAGTCCGAACGC-1 c1          0     1            1
#>  9 AATCGGTAGTGTTGAA-1 c1          0     1            1
#> 10 AATCGGTTCTGTCTAT-1 c1          0     1            1
#> # … with 369 more rows

Stored input data

  • get_input_segmentation to obtain information about the input DNA segmentation;
  • get_input_raw_data and get_counts to obtain the raw input data (i.e., single-cell counts) and the counts per segment used by CONGAS.

The input DNA segmentation is stored in the result of a CONGAS run. You can access that with get_input_segmentation and create simple filters based on chromosome ids.

Note that this tibble contains also columns that report the ploidy of the input segment (ploidy_real), the actual number of used genes retained that map to each segment (mu), and the total number of genes that map to the segments (fixed_mu).

Genes mapped to segments are filtered as explained in XXXX. Column segment_id is just a key to identify univocally the input segments to CONGAS.

# All the input segments
get_input_segmentation(congas_example)
#> # A tibble: 70 x 11
#>      size  start    end ploidy_real   tot   dist    mu fixed_mu chr     from
#>     <dbl>  <int>  <int>       <int> <int>  <int> <dbl>    <int> <chr>  <int>
#>  1 1.26e7 1.00e0 1.26e7           1     1 1.26e7    16       73 chr1  1.00e0
#>  2 4.75e7 1.26e7 6.02e7           2     2 4.75e7   102      302 chr1  1.26e7
#>  3 1.59e7 6.12e7 7.71e7           2     2 1.59e7    11       32 chr1  6.12e7
#>  4 7.72e7 7.88e7 1.56e8           2     2 7.72e7    87      261 chr1  7.88e7
#>  5 9.33e7 1.56e8 2.49e8           3     3 9.33e7   116      350 chr1  1.56e8
#>  6 2.62e7 1.00e0 2.62e7           1     1 2.62e7    15       56 chr2  1.00e0
#>  7 1.18e7 2.63e7 3.81e7           2     2 1.18e7    19       59 chr2  2.63e7
#>  8 2.31e7 6.41e7 8.72e7           2     2 2.31e7    35       95 chr2  6.41e7
#>  9 7.15e7 8.84e7 1.60e8           2     2 7.15e7    48      159 chr2  8.84e7
#> 10 1.69e7 1.60e8 1.77e8           1     1 1.69e7    11       35 chr2  1.60e8
#> # … with 60 more rows, and 1 more variable: to <int>

# Segments in chromosomes 1 to 3 (ids: chr1, chr2, chr3)
get_input_segmentation(congas_example, chromosomes = paste0('chr', 1:3))
#> # A tibble: 19 x 11
#>      size  start    end ploidy_real   tot   dist    mu fixed_mu chr     from
#>     <dbl>  <int>  <int>       <int> <int>  <int> <dbl>    <int> <chr>  <int>
#>  1 1.26e7 1.00e0 1.26e7           1     1 1.26e7    16       73 chr1  1.00e0
#>  2 4.75e7 1.26e7 6.02e7           2     2 4.75e7   102      302 chr1  1.26e7
#>  3 1.59e7 6.12e7 7.71e7           2     2 1.59e7    11       32 chr1  6.12e7
#>  4 7.72e7 7.88e7 1.56e8           2     2 7.72e7    87      261 chr1  7.88e7
#>  5 9.33e7 1.56e8 2.49e8           3     3 9.33e7   116      350 chr1  1.56e8
#>  6 2.62e7 1.00e0 2.62e7           1     1 2.62e7    15       56 chr2  1.00e0
#>  7 1.18e7 2.63e7 3.81e7           2     2 1.18e7    19       59 chr2  2.63e7
#>  8 2.31e7 6.41e7 8.72e7           2     2 2.31e7    35       95 chr2  6.41e7
#>  9 7.15e7 8.84e7 1.60e8           2     2 7.15e7    48      159 chr2  8.84e7
#> 10 1.69e7 1.60e8 1.77e8           1     1 1.69e7    11       35 chr2  1.60e8
#> 11 1.86e7 1.77e8 1.95e8           2     2 1.86e7    12       39 chr2  1.77e8
#> 12 4.15e7 2.02e8 2.43e8           2     2 4.15e7    42      134 chr2  2.02e8
#> 13 1.38e7 1.00e0 1.38e7           2     2 1.38e7    12       41 chr3  1.00e0
#> 14 5.25e7 3.44e7 8.68e7           1     1 5.25e7    41      165 chr3  3.44e7
#> 15 2.49e7 8.91e7 1.14e8           2     2 2.49e7    15       46 chr3  8.91e7
#> 16 2.01e7 1.14e8 1.34e8           3     3 2.01e7    28       76 chr3  1.14e8
#> 17 1.74e7 1.35e8 1.52e8           3     3 1.74e7    22       55 chr3  1.35e8
#> 18 2.83e7 1.52e8 1.80e8           4     4 2.83e7    18       50 chr3  1.52e8
#> 19 1.77e7 1.80e8 1.98e8           1     1 1.77e7    17       63 chr3  1.80e8
#> # … with 1 more variable: to <int>

If you have run the main rcongas fit function XXX by using parameters XXXX, the raw input RNA data matrix have also been stored into the fit object (otherwise no, just to save space in the final object).

You have a getter get_input_raw_data to obtain the input data when this has been stored in a rcongas object, or you need to load yourself the input data that you used to fit the model (in that case get_input_raw_data would return NULL and report a warning to screen). The raw input data are the counts, per gene (rows), per cell (columns), obtained from the scRNAseq experiment.

# Input data - stored inside "congas_example" in this case
raw_input_gene_by_cell = get_input_raw_data(congas_example)

# Just the 2x2 submatrix (genes on the rows, cells on the columns)
# print(raw_input_gene_by_cell[1:2, 1:2])

The data processed by CONGAS are counts mapped to segments, which are stored in a matrix that contains cells on rows, and segments on columns. This matrix can be extracted in long tidy format; the actual counts value can be obtained before or after normalisation, and can be subset to certain portions of the cancer genome.

In this long view we report also the cluster id for each of the input cells.

# Normalised data (default)
get_counts(congas_example)
#> # A tibble: 35,210 x 6
#>    chr    from       to cell                   n cluster
#>    <chr> <int>    <int> <chr>              <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 chr1      1 12600000 AAACCTGTCGACAGCC-1  22.0 c2     
#>  2 chr1      1 12600000 AAAGATGGTAATAGCA-1  24.5 c1     
#>  3 chr1      1 12600000 AACACGTAGCTATGCT-1  30.0 c1     
#>  4 chr1      1 12600000 AACTCCCAGACAGGCT-1  24.2 c2     
#>  5 chr1      1 12600000 AACTCCCGTACACCGC-1  30.6 c1     
#>  6 chr1      1 12600000 AACTGGTCAAAGAATC-1  18.6 c2     
#>  7 chr1      1 12600000 AACTGGTCAAAGTGCG-1  27.1 c1     
#>  8 chr1      1 12600000 AACTTTCGTGGCTCCA-1  29.1 c1     
#>  9 chr1      1 12600000 AACTTTCTCGGTTAAC-1  35.1 c2     
#> 10 chr1      1 12600000 AAGACCTAGCCAGTAG-1  14.5 c2     
#> # … with 35,200 more rows

# A view on a certain chromosome 
get_counts(congas_example,
           chromosomes = 'chr3')
#> # A tibble: 3,521 x 6
#>    chr    from       to cell                   n cluster
#>    <chr> <int>    <int> <chr>              <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 chr3      1 13800000 AAACCTGTCGACAGCC-1 24.6  c2     
#>  2 chr3      1 13800000 AAAGATGGTAATAGCA-1 28.4  c1     
#>  3 chr3      1 13800000 AACACGTAGCTATGCT-1 28.4  c1     
#>  4 chr3      1 13800000 AACTCCCAGACAGGCT-1 14.5  c2     
#>  5 chr3      1 13800000 AACTCCCGTACACCGC-1 29.0  c1     
#>  6 chr3      1 13800000 AACTGGTCAAAGAATC-1 16.4  c2     
#>  7 chr3      1 13800000 AACTGGTCAAAGTGCG-1  5.41 c1     
#>  8 chr3      1 13800000 AACTTTCGTGGCTCCA-1 25.5  c1     
#>  9 chr3      1 13800000 AACTTTCTCGGTTAAC-1 23.0  c2     
#> 10 chr3      1 13800000 AAGACCTAGCCAGTAG-1 17.1  c2     
#> # … with 3,511 more rows

# Un-normalised data
get_counts(congas_example, normalise = FALSE)
#> # A tibble: 35,210 x 6
#>    chr    from       to cell                   n cluster
#>    <chr> <int>    <int> <chr>              <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 chr1      1 12600000 AAACCTGTCGACAGCC-1    17 c2     
#>  2 chr1      1 12600000 AAAGATGGTAATAGCA-1    19 c1     
#>  3 chr1      1 12600000 AACACGTAGCTATGCT-1    18 c1     
#>  4 chr1      1 12600000 AACTCCCAGACAGGCT-1    20 c2     
#>  5 chr1      1 12600000 AACTCCCGTACACCGC-1    19 c1     
#>  6 chr1      1 12600000 AACTGGTCAAAGAATC-1    17 c2     
#>  7 chr1      1 12600000 AACTGGTCAAAGTGCG-1    15 c1     
#>  8 chr1      1 12600000 AACTTTCGTGGCTCCA-1    24 c1     
#>  9 chr1      1 12600000 AACTTTCTCGGTTAAC-1    32 c2     
#> 10 chr1      1 12600000 AAGACCTAGCCAGTAG-1    11 c2     
#> # … with 35,200 more rows

If you want to know what genes have been used by CONGAS and to which segments these have been mapped you can use function

# All mapped genes
get_mapped_genes(congas_example)
#> # A tibble: 8,564 x 4
#>    gene          chr   from  to      
#>    <chr>         <chr> <chr> <chr>   
#>  1 AP006222.2    chr1  1     12600000
#>  2 RP11.206L10.9 chr1  1     12600000
#>  3 FAM41C        chr1  1     12600000
#>  4 NOC2L         chr1  1     12600000
#>  5 ISG15         chr1  1     12600000
#>  6 AGRN          chr1  1     12600000
#>  7 C1orf159      chr1  1     12600000
#>  8 TTLL10        chr1  1     12600000
#>  9 PUSL1         chr1  1     12600000
#> 10 CPSF3L        chr1  1     12600000
#> # … with 8,554 more rows

# Genes mapped in chromosomes '1' and '5'
get_mapped_genes(congas_example, chromosomes = c('chr1', 'chr5'))
#> # A tibble: 1,377 x 4
#>    gene          chr   from  to      
#>    <chr>         <chr> <chr> <chr>   
#>  1 AP006222.2    chr1  1     12600000
#>  2 RP11.206L10.9 chr1  1     12600000
#>  3 FAM41C        chr1  1     12600000
#>  4 NOC2L         chr1  1     12600000
#>  5 ISG15         chr1  1     12600000
#>  6 AGRN          chr1  1     12600000
#>  7 C1orf159      chr1  1     12600000
#>  8 TTLL10        chr1  1     12600000
#>  9 PUSL1         chr1  1     12600000
#> 10 CPSF3L        chr1  1     12600000
#> # … with 1,367 more rows

Post-clustering analysis

  • get_DE_table to obtain results from DE analysis;

Results from Differential Expression (DE) analysis using Seurat are available by using get_DE_table. By default there are returned sorted by adjusted p-value, and filters can be applied to subset by maximum adjusted p-value (cut_pvalue), absolute log-fold change (cut_lfc), and chromosome id.

Note that the filters are applied jointly (i.e., as intersection).

# Default results (sorted by adjusted p-value, default filters)
get_DE_table(congas_example)
#> # A tibble: 162 x 8
#>    chr        from       to gene    pct_detec_1 ptc_detec_2 p_val_adj avg_log2FC
#>    <chr>     <int>    <int> <chr>         <dbl>       <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>
#>  1 chrX   71475529   7.15e7 RPS4X         1           1      2.34e-82     -0.570
#>  2 chrX    1505045   1.51e6 SLC25A6       0.997       1      1.18e-81     -0.823
#>  3 chrX   73040486   7.31e7 XIST          0.045       0.879  5.10e-54     -2.10 
#>  4 chr15  66790355   6.68e7 RPL4          1           1      8.87e-44      0.607
#>  5 chr16   2012053   2.01e6 RPS2          1           1      9.04e-36      0.757
#>  6 chr14 102547075   1.03e8 HSP90A…       1           1      1.10e-35      0.952
#>  7 chr1   39491990   3.95e7 NDUFS5        0.937       0.992  1.47e-31     -0.734
#>  8 chr6  133135580   1.33e8 RPS12         1           1      7.85e-30      0.363
#>  9 chr18  43664110   4.37e7 ATP5A1        0.995       0.927  1.06e-28      0.948
#> 10 chr6   29909037   2.99e7 HLA-A         1           1      2.13e-23     -0.869
#> # … with 152 more rows

# DE filtered by p-value cut at alpha-level 5%
get_DE_table(congas_example, cut_pvalue = 0.05)
#> # A tibble: 257 x 8
#>    chr        from       to gene    pct_detec_1 ptc_detec_2 p_val_adj avg_log2FC
#>    <chr>     <int>    <int> <chr>         <dbl>       <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>
#>  1 chrX   71475529   7.15e7 RPS4X         1           1      2.34e-82     -0.570
#>  2 chrX    1505045   1.51e6 SLC25A6       0.997       1      1.18e-81     -0.823
#>  3 chrX   73040486   7.31e7 XIST          0.045       0.879  5.10e-54     -2.10 
#>  4 chr15  66790355   6.68e7 RPL4          1           1      8.87e-44      0.607
#>  5 chr16   2012053   2.01e6 RPS2          1           1      9.04e-36      0.757
#>  6 chr14 102547075   1.03e8 HSP90A…       1           1      1.10e-35      0.952
#>  7 chr1   39491990   3.95e7 NDUFS5        0.937       0.992  1.47e-31     -0.734
#>  8 chr6  133135580   1.33e8 RPS12         1           1      7.85e-30      0.363
#>  9 chr18  43664110   4.37e7 ATP5A1        0.995       0.927  1.06e-28      0.948
#> 10 chr6   29909037   2.99e7 HLA-A         1           1      2.13e-23     -0.869
#> # … with 247 more rows

# DE filtered to retain all values, regardless the LFC
